chapters.title: ACT I. Algernon Moncrieff’s Flat in Half-Moon Street, W.

sentences: Morning-room in Algernon’s flat in Half-Moon Street.
The room is
luxuriously and artistically furnished.
The sound of a piano is heard
in the adjoining room.
Lane is arranging afternoon tea on the table, and after the music has
ceased, Algernon enters.
ALGERNON. Did you hear what I was playing, Lane?
LANE. I didn’t think it polite to listen, sir.
ALGERNON. I’m sorry for that, for your sake.
I don’t play accurately—any one can
ALGERNON. play accurately—but I play with wonderful expression.
As far as the
ALGERNON. piano is concerned, sentiment is my forte.
I keep science for Life.
LANE. Yes, sir.
ALGERNON. And, speaking of the science of Life, have you got the cucumber
ALGERNON. sandwiches cut for Lady Bracknell?
LANE. Yes, sir.
Hands them on a salver.
ALGERNON. Inspects them, takes two, and sits down on the sofa.
Oh!... by the
ALGERNON. way, Lane, I see from your book that on Thursday night, when Lord
ALGERNON. Shoreman and Mr. Worthing were dining with me, eight bottles of
ALGERNON. champagne are entered as having been consumed.
LANE. Yes, sir; eight bottles and a pint.
ALGERNON. Why is it that at a bachelor’s establishment the servants invariably
ALGERNON. drink the champagne?
I ask merely for information.
LANE. I attribute it to the superior quality of the wine, sir.
I have often
LANE. observed that in married households the champagne is rarely of a
LANE. first-rate brand.
ALGERNON. Good heavens!
Is marriage so demoralising as that?
LANE. I believe it _is_ a very pleasant state, sir.
I have had very little
LANE. experience of it myself up to the present.
I have only been married
LANE. That was in consequence of a misunderstanding between myself and
LANE. a young person.
ALGERNON. Languidly_._ I don’t know that I am much interested in your family
ALGERNON. life, Lane.
LANE. No, sir; it is not a very interesting subject.
I never think of it
LANE. myself.
ALGERNON. Very natural, I am sure.
That will do, Lane, thank you.
LANE. Thank you, sir.
Lane goes out.
ALGERNON. Lane’s views on marriage seem somewhat lax.
Really, if the lower orders
ALGERNON. don’t set us a good example, what on earth is the use of them?
ALGERNON. seem, as a class, to have absolutely no sense of moral responsibility.
ALGERNON. Enter Lane.
LANE. Mr. Ernest Worthing.
LANE. Enter Jack.
LANE. Lane goes out_._
ALGERNON. How are you, my dear Ernest?
What brings you up to town?
JACK. Oh, pleasure, pleasure!
What else should bring one anywhere?
Eating as
JACK. usual, I see, Algy!
ALGERNON. Stiffly_._ I believe it is customary in good society to take some
ALGERNON. slight refreshment at five o’clock.
Where have you been since last
ALGERNON. Thursday?
JACK. Sitting down on the sofa.
In the country.
ALGERNON. What on earth do you do there?
JACK. Pulling off his gloves_._ When one is in town one amuses oneself.
JACK. When one is in the country one amuses other people.
It is excessively
JACK. boring.
ALGERNON. And who are the people you amuse?
JACK. Airily_._ Oh, neighbours, neighbours.
ALGERNON. Got nice neighbours in your part of Shropshire?
JACK. Perfectly horrid!
Never speak to one of them.
ALGERNON. How immensely you must amuse them!
Goes over and takes sandwich.
ALGERNON. the way, Shropshire is your county, is it not?
JACK. Eh?
Shropshire?
Yes, of course.
Hallo!
Why all these cups?
Why cucumber
JACK. sandwiches?
Why such reckless extravagance in one so young?
Who is
JACK. coming to tea?
ALGERNON. Oh! merely Aunt Augusta and Gwendolen.
JACK. How perfectly delightful!
ALGERNON. Yes, that is all very well; but I am afraid Aunt Augusta won’t quite
ALGERNON. approve of your being here.
JACK. May I ask why?
ALGERNON. My dear fellow, the way you flirt with Gwendolen is perfectly
ALGERNON. disgraceful.
It is almost as bad as the way Gwendolen flirts with you.
JACK. I am in love with Gwendolen.
I have come up to town expressly to
JACK. propose to her.
ALGERNON. I thought you had come up for pleasure?... I call that business.
JACK. How utterly unromantic you are!
ALGERNON. I really don’t see anything romantic in proposing.
It is very romantic
ALGERNON. to be in love.
But there is nothing romantic about a definite proposal.
ALGERNON. Why, one may be accepted.
One usually is, I believe.
Then the
ALGERNON. excitement is all over.
The very essence of romance is uncertainty.
ALGERNON. ever I get married, I’ll certainly try to forget the fact.
JACK. I have no doubt about that, dear Algy.
The Divorce Court was specially
JACK. invented for people whose memories are so curiously constituted.
ALGERNON. Oh! there is no use speculating on that subject.
Divorces are made in
ALGERNON. Heaven—Jack puts out his hand to take a sandwich.
Algernon at once
ALGERNON. interferes.
Please don’t touch the cucumber sandwiches.
They are
ALGERNON. ordered specially for Aunt Augusta.
Takes one and eats it.
JACK. Well, you have been eating them all the time.
ALGERNON. That is quite a different matter.
She is my aunt.
Takes plate from
ALGERNON. below.
Have some bread and butter.
The bread and butter is for
ALGERNON. Gwendolen.
Gwendolen is devoted to bread and butter.
JACK. Advancing to table and helping himself.
And very good bread and
JACK. butter it is too.
ALGERNON. Well, my dear fellow, you need not eat as if you were going to eat it
ALGERNON. You behave as if you were married to her already.
You are not
ALGERNON. married to her already, and I don’t think you ever will be.
JACK. Why on earth do you say that?
ALGERNON. Well, in the first place girls never marry the men they flirt with.
ALGERNON. Girls don’t think it right.
JACK. Oh, that is nonsense!
ALGERNON. It isn’t.
It is a great truth.
It accounts for the extraordinary number
ALGERNON. of bachelors that one sees all over the place.
In the second place, I
ALGERNON. don’t give my consent.
JACK. Your consent!
ALGERNON. My dear fellow, Gwendolen is my first cousin.
And before I allow you to
ALGERNON. marry her, you will have to clear up the whole question of Cecily.
ALGERNON. Rings bell.
JACK. Cecily!
What on earth do you mean?
What do you mean, Algy, by Cecily!
I
JACK. don’t know any one of the name of Cecily.
JACK. Enter Lane.
ALGERNON. Bring me that cigarette case Mr. Worthing left in the smoking-room the
ALGERNON. last time he dined here.
LANE. Yes, sir.
Lane goes out.
JACK. Do you mean to say you have had my cigarette case all this time?
I wish
JACK. to goodness you had let me know.
I have been writing frantic letters to
JACK. Scotland Yard about it.
I was very nearly offering a large reward.
ALGERNON. Well, I wish you would offer one.
I happen to be more than usually hard
JACK. There is no good offering a large reward now that the thing is found.
JACK. Enter Lane with the cigarette case on a salver.
Algernon takes it at
JACK. Lane goes out.
ALGERNON. I think that is rather mean of you, Ernest, I must say.
Opens case and
ALGERNON. examines it.
However, it makes no matter, for, now that I look at the
ALGERNON. inscription inside, I find that the thing isn’t yours after all.
JACK. Of course it’s mine.
Moving to him.
You have seen me with it a
JACK. hundred times, and you have no right whatsoever to read what is written
JACK. inside.
It is a very ungentlemanly thing to read a private cigarette
ALGERNON. Oh! it is absurd to have a hard and fast rule about what one should
ALGERNON. read and what one shouldn’t.
More than half of modern culture depends
ALGERNON. on what one shouldn’t read.
JACK. I am quite aware of the fact, and I don’t propose to discuss modern
JACK. culture.
It isn’t the sort of thing one should talk of in private.
I
JACK. simply want my cigarette case back.
ALGERNON. Yes; but this isn’t your cigarette case.
This cigarette case is a
ALGERNON. present from some one of the name of Cecily, and you said you didn’t
ALGERNON. know any one of that name.
JACK. Well, if you want to know, Cecily happens to be my aunt.
ALGERNON. Your aunt!
JACK. Yes.
Charming old lady she is, too.
Lives at Tunbridge Wells.
Just give
JACK. it back to me, Algy.
ALGERNON. Retreating to back of sofa.
But why does she call herself little
ALGERNON. Cecily if she is your aunt and lives at Tunbridge Wells?
Reading.
ALGERNON. ‘From little Cecily with her fondest love.’
JACK. Moving to sofa and kneeling upon it.
My dear fellow, what on earth is
JACK. there in that?
Some aunts are tall, some aunts are not tall.
That is a
JACK. matter that surely an aunt may be allowed to decide for herself.
JACK. seem to think that every aunt should be exactly like your aunt!
That is
JACK. absurd!
For Heaven’s sake give me back my cigarette case.
Follows
JACK. Algernon round the room.
ALGERNON. Yes.
But why does your aunt call you her uncle? ‘From little Cecily,
ALGERNON. with her fondest love to her dear Uncle Jack.’ There is no objection, I
ALGERNON. admit, to an aunt being a small aunt, but why an aunt, no matter what
ALGERNON. her size may be, should call her own nephew her uncle, I can’t quite
ALGERNON. make out.
Besides, your name isn’t Jack at all; it is Ernest.
JACK. It isn’t Ernest; it’s Jack.
ALGERNON. You have always told me it was Ernest.
I have introduced you to every
ALGERNON. one as Ernest.
You answer to the name of Ernest.
You look as if your
ALGERNON. name was Ernest.
You are the most earnest-looking person I ever saw in
ALGERNON. my life.
It is perfectly absurd your saying that your name isn’t
ALGERNON. Ernest.
It’s on your cards.
Here is one of them.
Taking it from case.
ALGERNON. ‘Mr. Ernest Worthing, B. 4, The Albany.’ I’ll keep this as a proof that
ALGERNON. your name is Ernest if ever you attempt to deny it to me, or to
ALGERNON. Gwendolen, or to any one else.
Puts the card in his pocket.
JACK. Well, my name is Ernest in town and Jack in the country, and the
JACK. cigarette case was given to me in the country.
ALGERNON. Yes, but that does not account for the fact that your small Aunt
ALGERNON. Cecily, who lives at Tunbridge Wells, calls you her dear uncle.
ALGERNON. old boy, you had much better have the thing out at once.
JACK. My dear Algy, you talk exactly as if you were a dentist.
It is very
JACK. vulgar to talk like a dentist when one isn’t a dentist.
It produces a
JACK. false impression.
ALGERNON. Well, that is exactly what dentists always do.
Now, go on!
Tell me the
ALGERNON. whole thing.
I may mention that I have always suspected you of being a
ALGERNON. confirmed and secret Bunburyist; and I am quite sure of it now.
JACK. Bunburyist?
What on earth do you mean by a Bunburyist?
ALGERNON. I’ll reveal to you the meaning of that incomparable expression as soon
ALGERNON. as you are kind enough to inform me why you are Ernest in town and Jack
ALGERNON. in the country.
JACK. Well, produce my cigarette case first.
ALGERNON. Here it is.
Hands cigarette case.
Now produce your explanation, and
ALGERNON. pray make it improbable.
Sits on sofa.
JACK. My dear fellow, there is nothing improbable about my explanation at
JACK. In fact it’s perfectly ordinary.
Old Mr. Thomas Cardew, who
JACK. adopted me when I was a little boy, made me in his will guardian to his
JACK. grand-daughter, Miss Cecily Cardew.
Cecily, who addresses me as her
JACK. uncle from motives of respect that you could not possibly appreciate,
JACK. lives at my place in the country under the charge of her admirable
JACK. governess, Miss Prism.
ALGERNON. Where is that place in the country, by the way?
JACK. That is nothing to you, dear boy.
You are not going to be invited...
JACK. I may tell you candidly that the place is not in Shropshire.
ALGERNON. I suspected that, my dear fellow!
I have Bunburyed all over Shropshire
ALGERNON. on two separate occasions.
Now, go on.
Why are you Ernest in town and
ALGERNON. Jack in the country?
JACK. My dear Algy, I don’t know whether you will be able to understand my
JACK. real motives.
You are hardly serious enough.
When one is placed in the
JACK. position of guardian, one has to adopt a very high moral tone on all
JACK. subjects.
It’s one’s duty to do so.
And as a high moral tone can hardly
JACK. be said to conduce very much to either one’s health or one’s happiness,
JACK. in order to get up to town I have always pretended to have a younger
JACK. brother of the name of Ernest, who lives in the Albany, and gets into
JACK. the most dreadful scrapes.
That, my dear Algy, is the whole truth pure
JACK. and simple.
ALGERNON. The truth is rarely pure and never simple.
Modern life would be very
ALGERNON. tedious if it were either, and modern literature a complete
ALGERNON. impossibility!
JACK. That wouldn’t be at all a bad thing.
ALGERNON. Literary criticism is not your forte, my dear fellow.
Don’t try it.
ALGERNON. should leave that to people who haven’t been at a University.
They do
ALGERNON. it so well in the daily papers.
What you really are is a Bunburyist.
I
ALGERNON. was quite right in saying you were a Bunburyist.
You are one of the
ALGERNON. most advanced Bunburyists I know.
JACK. What on earth do you mean?
ALGERNON. You have invented a very useful younger brother called Ernest, in order
ALGERNON. that you may be able to come up to town as often as you like.
I have
ALGERNON. invented an invaluable permanent invalid called Bunbury, in order that
ALGERNON. I may be able to go down into the country whenever I choose.
Bunbury is
ALGERNON. perfectly invaluable.
If it wasn’t for Bunbury’s extraordinary bad
ALGERNON. health, for instance, I wouldn’t be able to dine with you at Willis’s
ALGERNON. to-night, for I have been really engaged to Aunt Augusta for more than
ALGERNON. a week.
JACK. I haven’t asked you to dine with me anywhere to-night.
ALGERNON. I know.
You are absurdly careless about sending out invitations.
ALGERNON. very foolish of you.
Nothing annoys people so much as not receiving
ALGERNON. invitations.
JACK. You had much better dine with your Aunt Augusta.
ALGERNON. I haven’t the smallest intention of doing anything of the kind.
ALGERNON. begin with, I dined there on Monday, and once a week is quite enough to
ALGERNON. dine with one’s own relations.
In the second place, whenever I do dine
ALGERNON. there I am always treated as a member of the family, and sent down with
ALGERNON. either no woman at all, or two.
In the third place, I know perfectly
ALGERNON. well whom she will place me next to, to-night.
She will place me next
ALGERNON. Mary Farquhar, who always flirts with her own husband across the
ALGERNON. dinner-table.
That is not very pleasant.
Indeed, it is not even decent... and that sort of thing is enormously on the increase.
The amount
ALGERNON. of women in London who flirt with their own husbands is perfectly
ALGERNON. scandalous.
It looks so bad.
It is simply washing one’s clean linen in
ALGERNON. public.
Besides, now that I know you to be a confirmed Bunburyist I
ALGERNON. naturally want to talk to you about Bunburying.
I want to tell you the
ALGERNON. rules.
JACK. I’m not a Bunburyist at all.
If Gwendolen accepts me, I am going to
JACK. kill my brother, indeed I think I’ll kill him in any case.
Cecily is a
JACK. little too much interested in him.
It is rather a bore.
So I am going
JACK. to get rid of Ernest.
And I strongly advise you to do the same with Mr.... with your invalid friend who has the absurd name.
ALGERNON. Nothing will induce me to part with Bunbury, and if you ever get
ALGERNON. married, which seems to me extremely problematic, you will be very glad
ALGERNON. to know Bunbury.
A man who marries without knowing Bunbury has a very
ALGERNON. tedious time of it.
JACK. That is nonsense.
If I marry a charming girl like Gwendolen, and she is
JACK. the only girl I ever saw in my life that I would marry, I certainly
JACK. won’t want to know Bunbury.
ALGERNON. Then your wife will.
You don’t seem to realise, that in married life
ALGERNON. three is company and two is none.
JACK. Sententiously.
That, my dear young friend, is the theory that the
JACK. corrupt French Drama has been propounding for the last fifty years.
ALGERNON. Yes; and that the happy English home has proved in half the time.
JACK. For heaven’s sake, don’t try to be cynical.
It’s perfectly easy to be
JACK. cynical.
ALGERNON. My dear fellow, it isn’t easy to be anything nowadays.
There’s such a
ALGERNON. lot of beastly competition about.
The sound of an electric bell is
ALGERNON. heard.
Ah! that must be Aunt Augusta.
Only relatives, or creditors,
ALGERNON. ever ring in that Wagnerian manner.
Now, if I get her out of the way
ALGERNON. for ten minutes, so that you can have an opportunity for proposing to
ALGERNON. Gwendolen, may I dine with you to-night at Willis’s?
JACK. I suppose so, if you want to.
ALGERNON. Yes, but you must be serious about it.
I hate people who are not
ALGERNON. serious about meals.
It is so shallow of them.
ALGERNON. Enter Lane.
LANE. Lady Bracknell and Miss Fairfax.
LANE. Algernon goes forward to meet them.
Enter Lady Bracknell and
LANE. Gwendolen.
LANE. LADY BRACKNELL.
LANE. Good afternoon, dear Algernon, I hope you are behaving very well.
ALGERNON. I’m feeling very well, Aunt Augusta.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. That’s not quite the same thing.
In fact the two things rarely go
ALGERNON. together.
Sees Jack and bows to him with icy coldness.
ALGERNON. To Gwendolen.
Dear me, you are smart!
GWENDOLEN. I am always smart!
Am I not, Mr. Worthing?
JACK. You’re quite perfect, Miss Fairfax.
GWENDOLEN. Oh!
I hope I am not that.
It would leave no room for developments, and
GWENDOLEN. I intend to develop in many directions.
Gwendolen and Jack sit down
GWENDOLEN. together in the corner.
GWENDOLEN. LADY BRACKNELL.
GWENDOLEN. I’m sorry if we are a little late, Algernon, but I was obliged to call
GWENDOLEN. on dear Lady Harbury.
I hadn’t been there since her poor husband’s
GWENDOLEN. death.
I never saw a woman so altered; she looks quite twenty years
GWENDOLEN. younger.
And now I’ll have a cup of tea, and one of those nice cucumber
GWENDOLEN. sandwiches you promised me.
ALGERNON. Certainly, Aunt Augusta.
Goes over to tea-table.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. Won’t you come and sit here, Gwendolen?
GWENDOLEN. Thanks, mamma, I’m quite comfortable where I am.
ALGERNON. Picking up empty plate in horror.
Good heavens!
Lane!
Why are there
ALGERNON. no cucumber sandwiches?
I ordered them specially.
LANE. Gravely.
There were no cucumbers in the market this morning, sir.
I
LANE. went down twice.
ALGERNON. No cucumbers!
LANE. No, sir.
Not even for ready money.
ALGERNON. That will do, Lane, thank you.
LANE. Thank you, sir.
Goes out.
ALGERNON. I am greatly distressed, Aunt Augusta, about there being no cucumbers,
ALGERNON. not even for ready money.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. It really makes no matter, Algernon.
I had some crumpets with Lady
ALGERNON. Harbury, who seems to me to be living entirely for pleasure now.
ALGERNON. I hear her hair has turned quite gold from grief.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. It certainly has changed its colour.
From what cause I, of course,
ALGERNON. cannot say.
Algernon crosses and hands tea.
Thank you.
I’ve quite a
ALGERNON. treat for you to-night, Algernon.
I am going to send you down with Mary
ALGERNON. Farquhar.
She is such a nice woman, and so attentive to her husband.
ALGERNON. It’s delightful to watch them.
ALGERNON. I am afraid, Aunt Augusta, I shall have to give up the pleasure of
ALGERNON. dining with you to-night after all.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. Frowning.
I hope not, Algernon.
It would put my table completely out.
ALGERNON. Your uncle would have to dine upstairs.
Fortunately he is accustomed to
ALGERNON. It is a great bore, and, I need hardly say, a terrible disappointment
ALGERNON. to me, but the fact is I have just had a telegram to say that my poor
ALGERNON. friend Bunbury is very ill again.
Exchanges glances with Jack.
ALGERNON. seem to think I should be with him.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. It is very strange.
This Mr. Bunbury seems to suffer from curiously bad
ALGERNON. health.
ALGERNON. Yes; poor Bunbury is a dreadful invalid.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. Well, I must say, Algernon, that I think it is high time that Mr.
ALGERNON. Bunbury made up his mind whether he was going to live or to die.
ALGERNON. shilly-shallying with the question is absurd.
Nor do I in any way
ALGERNON. approve of the modern sympathy with invalids.
I consider it morbid.
ALGERNON. Illness of any kind is hardly a thing to be encouraged in others.
ALGERNON. Health is the primary duty of life.
I am always telling that to your
ALGERNON. poor uncle, but he never seems to take much notice... as far as any
ALGERNON. improvement in his ailment goes.
I should be much obliged if you would
ALGERNON. ask Mr. Bunbury, from me, to be kind enough not to have a relapse on
ALGERNON. Saturday, for I rely on you to arrange my music for me.
It is my last
ALGERNON. reception, and one wants something that will encourage conversation,
ALGERNON. particularly at the end of the season when every one has practically
ALGERNON. said whatever they had to say, which, in most cases, was probably not
ALGERNON. I’ll speak to Bunbury, Aunt Augusta, if he is still conscious, and I
ALGERNON. think I can promise you he’ll be all right by Saturday.
Of course the
ALGERNON. music is a great difficulty.
You see, if one plays good music, people
ALGERNON. don’t listen, and if one plays bad music people don’t talk.
But I’ll
ALGERNON. run over the programme I’ve drawn out, if you will kindly come into the
ALGERNON. next room for a moment.
ALGERNON. LADY BRACKNELL.
ALGERNON. Thank you, Algernon.
It is very thoughtful of you.
Rising, and
ALGERNON. following Algernon.
I’m sure the programme will be delightful, after a
ALGERNON. few expurgations.
French songs I cannot possibly allow.
People always
ALGERNON. seem to think that they are improper, and either look shocked, which is
ALGERNON. vulgar, or laugh, which is worse.
But German sounds a thoroughly
ALGERNON. respectable language, and indeed, I believe is so.
Gwendolen, you will
ALGERNON. accompany me.
GWENDOLEN. Certainly, mamma.
GWENDOLEN. Lady Bracknell and Algernon go into the music-room, Gwendolen remains
GWENDOLEN. behind.
JACK. Charming day it has been, Miss Fairfax.
GWENDOLEN. Pray don’t talk to me about the weather, Mr. Worthing.
Whenever people
GWENDOLEN. talk to me about the weather, I always feel quite certain that they
GWENDOLEN. mean something else.
And that makes me so nervous.
JACK. I _do_ mean something else.
GWENDOLEN. I thought so.
In fact, I am never wrong.
JACK. And I would like to be allowed to take advantage of Lady Bracknell’s
JACK. temporary absence...
GWENDOLEN. I would certainly advise you to do so.
Mamma has a way of coming back
GWENDOLEN. suddenly into a room that I have often had to speak to her about.
JACK. Nervously.
Miss Fairfax, ever since I met you I have admired you more
JACK. than any girl... I have ever met since... I met you.
GWENDOLEN. Yes, I am quite well aware of the fact.
And I often wish that in
GWENDOLEN. public, at any rate, you had been more demonstrative.
For me you have
GWENDOLEN. always had an irresistible fascination.
Even before I met you I was far
GWENDOLEN. from indifferent to you.
Jack looks at her in amazement.
We live, as
GWENDOLEN. I hope you know, Mr. Worthing, in an age of ideals.
The fact is
GWENDOLEN. constantly mentioned in the more expensive monthly magazines, and has
GWENDOLEN. reached the provincial pulpits, I am told; and my ideal has always been
GWENDOLEN. to love some one of the name of Ernest.
There is something in that name
GWENDOLEN. that inspires absolute confidence.
The moment Algernon first mentioned
GWENDOLEN. to me that he had a friend called Ernest, I knew I was destined to love
JACK. You really love me, Gwendolen?
GWENDOLEN. Passionately!
JACK. Darling!
You don’t know how happy you’ve made me.
GWENDOLEN. My own Ernest!
JACK. But you don’t really mean to say that you couldn’t love me if my name
JACK. wasn’t Ernest?
GWENDOLEN. But your name is Ernest.
JACK. Yes, I know it is.
But supposing it was something else?
Do you mean to
JACK. say you couldn’t love me then?
GWENDOLEN. Glibly.
Ah! that is clearly a metaphysical speculation, and like most
GWENDOLEN. metaphysical speculations has very little reference at all to the
GWENDOLEN. actual facts of real life, as we know them.
JACK. Personally, darling, to speak quite candidly, I don’t much care about
JACK. the name of Ernest... I don’t think the name suits me at all.
GWENDOLEN. It suits you perfectly.
It is a divine name.
It has a music of its own.
GWENDOLEN. It produces vibrations.

GWENDOLEN. more than usually plain.

GWENDOLEN. would probably never be allowed to know the entrancing pleasure of a

JACK. Gwendolen, I must get christened at once—I mean we must get married at

JACK. Astounded.

GWENDOLEN. I adore you.

GWENDOLEN. at all about marriage.

GWENDOLEN. possible disappointment, Mr. Worthing, I think it only fair to tell you

GWENDOLEN. Of course I will, darling.

GWENDOLEN. you have had very little experience in how to propose.
JACK. My own one, I have never loved any one in the world but you.
GWENDOLEN. Yes, but men often propose for practice.

GWENDOLEN. All my girl-friends tell me so.

GWENDOLEN. Lady Bracknell.
GWENDOLEN. LADY BRACKNELL.
GWENDOLEN. Mr. Worthing!

It is most
GWENDOLEN. indecorous.
GWENDOLEN. Mamma!

GWENDOLEN. LADY BRACKNELL.
GWENDOLEN. Pardon me, you are not engaged to any one.

GWENDOLEN. inform you of the fact.

GWENDOLEN. surprise, pleasant or unpleasant, as the case may be.
It is hardly a
GWENDOLEN. matter that she could be allowed to arrange for herself... And now I
GWENDOLEN. have a few questions to put to you, Mr. Worthing.

GWENDOLEN. these inquiries, you, Gwendolen, will wait for me below in the
GWENDOLEN. carriage.
GWENDOLEN. Reproachfully.
Mamma!
GWENDOLEN. LADY BRACKNELL.
GWENDOLEN. In the carriage, Gwendolen!

She and Jack
GWENDOLEN. blow kisses to each other behind Lady Bracknell’s back.
Lady Bracknell
GWENDOLEN. looks vaguely about as if she could not understand what the noise was.
GWENDOLEN. Finally turns round.
Gwendolen, the carriage!
GWENDOLEN. Yes, mamma.

GWENDOLEN. LADY BRACKNELL.
GWENDOLEN. Sitting down.
You can take a seat, Mr. Worthing.
GWENDOLEN. Looks in her pocket for note-book and pencil.
JACK. Thank you, Lady Bracknell, I prefer standing.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Pencil and note-book in hand.
I feel bound to tell you that you are
JACK. not down on my list of eligible young men, although I have the same
JACK. list as the dear Duchess of Bolton has.

JACK. However, I am quite ready to enter your name, should your answers be
JACK. what a really affectionate mother requires.

JACK. Well, yes, I must admit I smoke.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. I am glad to hear it.
A man should always have an occupation of some
JACK. There are far too many idle men in London as it is.
How old are
JACK. Twenty-nine.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. A very good age to be married at.

JACK. man who desires to get married should know either everything or

JACK. After some hesitation.

JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. I am pleased to hear it.
I do not approve of anything that tampers with
JACK. natural ignorance.

JACK. and the bloom is gone.

JACK. radically unsound.

JACK. produces no effect whatsoever.

JACK. danger to the upper classes, and probably lead to acts of violence in
JACK. Grosvenor Square.

JACK. Between seven and eight thousand a year.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Makes a note in her book.

JACK. In investments, chiefly.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. That is satisfactory.
What between the duties expected of one during
JACK. one’s lifetime, and the duties exacted from one after one’s death, land
JACK. has ceased to be either a profit or a pleasure.
It gives one position,
JACK. and prevents one from keeping it up.
That’s all that can be said about

JACK. fifteen hundred acres, I believe; but I don’t depend on that for my
JACK. real income.

JACK. only people who make anything out of it.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. A country house!
How many bedrooms?
Well, that point can be cleared up
JACK. afterwards.
You have a town house, I hope?

JACK. unspoiled nature, like Gwendolen, could hardly be expected to reside in
JACK. the country.
JACK. Well, I own a house in Belgrave Square, but it is let by the year to
JACK. Lady Bloxham.

JACK. months’ notice.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Lady Bloxham?
I don’t know her.
JACK. Oh, she goes about very little.
She is a lady considerably advanced in
JACK. years.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Ah, nowadays that is no guarantee of respectability of character.
JACK. number in Belgrave Square?
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Shaking her head.
The unfashionable side.
I thought there was
JACK. something.

JACK. Do you mean the fashion, or the side?
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Sternly.
Both, if necessary, I presume.

JACK. Well, I am afraid I really have none.
I am a Liberal Unionist.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Oh, they count as Tories.
They dine with us.
Or come in the evening, at
JACK. any rate.

JACK. I have lost both my parents.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. To lose one parent, Mr. Worthing, may be regarded as a misfortune; to
JACK. lose both looks like carelessness.

He was
JACK. evidently a man of some wealth.

JACK. call the purple of commerce, or did he rise from the ranks of the
JACK. aristocracy?
JACK. I am afraid I really don’t know.
The fact is, Lady Bracknell, I said I
JACK. had lost my parents.
It would be nearer the truth to say that my
JACK. parents seem to have lost me... I don’t actually know who I am by
JACK. birth.
I was... well, I was found.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Found!
JACK. The late Mr. Thomas Cardew, an old gentleman of a very charitable and
JACK. kindly disposition, found me, and gave me the name of Worthing, because
JACK. he happened to have a first-class ticket for Worthing in his pocket at
JACK. the time.
Worthing is a place in Sussex.
It is a seaside resort.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Where did the charitable gentleman who had a first-class ticket for

JACK. Gravely.
In a hand-bag.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. A hand-bag?
JACK. Very seriously.
Yes, Lady Bracknell.

JACK. large, black leather hand-bag, with handles to it—an ordinary hand-bag
JACK. in fact.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. In what locality did this Mr. James, or Thomas, Cardew come across this
JACK. ordinary hand-bag?
JACK. In the cloak-room at Victoria Station.

JACK. for his own.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. The cloak-room at Victoria Station?
JACK. Yes.
The Brighton line.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. The line is immaterial.
Mr. Worthing, I confess I feel somewhat
JACK. bewildered by what you have just told me.

JACK. bred, in a hand-bag, whether it had handles or not, seems to me to
JACK. display a contempt for the ordinary decencies of family life that
JACK. reminds one of the worst excesses of the French Revolution.
JACK. presume you know what that unfortunate movement led to?
As for the
JACK. particular locality in which the hand-bag was found, a cloak-room at a
JACK. railway station might serve to conceal a social indiscretion—has
JACK. probably, indeed, been used for that purpose before now—but it could
JACK. hardly be regarded as an assured basis for a recognised position in
JACK. good society.
JACK. May I ask you then what you would advise me to do?
I need hardly say I
JACK. would do anything in the world to ensure Gwendolen’s happiness.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. I would strongly advise you, Mr. Worthing, to try and acquire some
JACK. relations as soon as possible, and to make a definite effort to produce
JACK. at any rate one parent, of either sex, before the season is quite over.
JACK. Well, I don’t see how I could possibly manage to do that.
I can produce
JACK. the hand-bag at any moment.
It is in my dressing-room at home.
I really
JACK. think that should satisfy you, Lady Bracknell.
JACK. LADY BRACKNELL.
JACK. Me, sir!
What has it to do with me?
You can hardly imagine that I and
JACK. Lord Bracknell would dream of allowing our only daughter—a girl brought
JACK. up with the utmost care—to marry into a cloak-room, and form an
JACK. alliance with a parcel?
Good morning, Mr. Worthing!
JACK. Lady Bracknell sweeps out in majestic indignation.
JACK. Good morning!
Algernon, from the other room, strikes up the Wedding
JACK. March.
Jack looks perfectly furious, and goes to the door.
JACK. goodness’ sake don’t play that ghastly tune, Algy.

JACK. The music stops and Algernon enters cheerily.
ALGERNON. Didn’t it go off all right, old boy?
You don’t mean to say Gwendolen
ALGERNON. refused you?
I know it is a way she has.

ALGERNON. I think it is most ill-natured of her.
JACK. Oh, Gwendolen is as right as a trivet.
As far as she is concerned, we
JACK. are engaged.
Her mother is perfectly unbearable.
Never met such a
JACK. Gorgon... I don’t really know what a Gorgon is like, but I am quite
JACK. sure that Lady Bracknell is one.

JACK. being a myth, which is rather unfair... I beg your pardon, Algy, I
JACK. suppose I shouldn’t talk about your own aunt in that way before you.
ALGERNON. My dear boy, I love hearing my relations abused.
It is the only thing
ALGERNON. that makes me put up with them at all.

ALGERNON. pack of people, who haven’t got the remotest knowledge of how to live,
ALGERNON. nor the smallest instinct about when to die.
JACK. Oh, that is nonsense!
ALGERNON. It isn’t!
JACK. Well, I won’t argue about the matter.
You always want to argue about
JACK. things.
ALGERNON. That is exactly what things were originally made for.
JACK. Upon my word, if I thought that, I’d shoot myself... A pause.
JACK. don’t think there is any chance of Gwendolen becoming like her mother
JACK. in about a hundred and fifty years, do you, Algy?
ALGERNON. All women become like their mothers.
That is their tragedy.
No man
ALGERNON. That’s his.
JACK. Is that clever?
ALGERNON. It is perfectly phrased! and quite as true as any observation in
ALGERNON. civilised life should be.
JACK. I am sick to death of cleverness.
Everybody is clever nowadays.
JACK. can’t go anywhere without meeting clever people.
The thing has become
JACK. an absolute public nuisance.
I wish to goodness we had a few fools
ALGERNON. We have.
JACK. I should extremely like to meet them.

ALGERNON. The fools?

JACK. What fools!
ALGERNON. By the way, did you tell Gwendolen the truth about your being Ernest in
ALGERNON. town, and Jack in the country?
JACK. In a very patronising manner.

JACK. the sort of thing one tells to a nice, sweet, refined girl.
JACK. extraordinary ideas you have about the way to behave to a woman!
ALGERNON. The only way to behave to a woman is to make love to her, if she is
ALGERNON. pretty, and to some one else, if she is plain.
JACK. Oh, that is nonsense.
ALGERNON. What about your brother?

JACK. Oh, before the end of the week I shall have got rid of him.
I’ll say he
JACK. died in Paris of apoplexy.

JACK. suddenly, don’t they?
ALGERNON. Yes, but it’s hereditary, my dear fellow.

ALGERNON. runs in families.

JACK. You are sure a severe chill isn’t hereditary, or anything of that kind?
ALGERNON. Of course it isn’t!
JACK. Very well, then.
My poor brother Ernest is carried off suddenly, in
JACK. Paris, by a severe chill.
That gets rid of him.
ALGERNON. But I thought you said that... Miss Cardew was a little too much
ALGERNON. interested in your poor brother Ernest?
Won’t she feel his loss a good
JACK. Oh, that is all right.
Cecily is not a silly romantic girl, I am glad
JACK. to say.
She has got a capital appetite, goes long walks, and pays no
JACK. attention at all to her lessons.
ALGERNON. I would rather like to see Cecily.
JACK. I will take very good care you never do.
She is excessively pretty, and
JACK. she is only just eighteen.
ALGERNON. Have you told Gwendolen yet that you have an excessively pretty ward
ALGERNON. who is only just eighteen?
JACK. Oh! one doesn’t blurt these things out to people.
Cecily and Gwendolen
JACK. are perfectly certain to be extremely great friends.
I’ll bet you
JACK. anything you like that half an hour after they have met, they will be
JACK. calling each other sister.
ALGERNON. Women only do that when they have called each other a lot of other
ALGERNON. things first.
Now, my dear boy, if we want to get a good table at
ALGERNON. Willis’s, we really must go and dress.
Do you know it is nearly seven?
JACK. Irritably.
Oh!

ALGERNON. Well, I’m hungry.
JACK. I never knew you when you weren’t...
ALGERNON. What shall we do after dinner?

JACK. Oh no!

ALGERNON. Well, let us go to the Club?
JACK. Oh, no!

ALGERNON. Well, we might trot round to the Empire at ten?
JACK. Oh, no!

ALGERNON. Well, what shall we do?
JACK. Nothing!
ALGERNON. It is awfully hard work doing nothing.

ALGERNON. Enter Lane.
LANE. Miss Fairfax.
LANE. Enter Gwendolen.
Lane goes out.
ALGERNON. Gwendolen, upon my word!
GWENDOLEN. Algy, kindly turn your back.
I have something very particular to say to
GWENDOLEN. Mr. Worthing.
ALGERNON. Really, Gwendolen, I don’t think I can allow this at all.
GWENDOLEN. Algy, you always adopt a strictly immoral attitude towards life.
GWENDOLEN. are not quite old enough to do that.

GWENDOLEN. fireplace.
JACK. My own darling!
GWENDOLEN. Ernest, we may never be married.

GWENDOLEN. fear we never shall.

GWENDOLEN. children say to them.
The old-fashioned respect for the young is fast
GWENDOLEN. dying out.
Whatever influence I ever had over mamma, I lost at the age
GWENDOLEN. of three.

GWENDOLEN. and I may marry some one else, and marry often, nothing that she can
GWENDOLEN. possibly do can alter my eternal devotion to you.
JACK. Dear Gwendolen!
GWENDOLEN. The story of your romantic origin, as related to me by mamma, with
GWENDOLEN. unpleasing comments, has naturally stirred the deeper fibres of my
GWENDOLEN. nature.
Your Christian name has an irresistible fascination.
GWENDOLEN. simplicity of your character makes you exquisitely incomprehensible to
GWENDOLEN. Your town address at the Albany I have.

GWENDOLEN. country?
JACK. The Manor House, Woolton, Hertfordshire.
JACK. Algernon, who has been carefully listening, smiles to himself, and
JACK. writes the address on his shirt-cuff.

GWENDOLEN. There is a good postal service, I suppose?
It may be necessary to do
GWENDOLEN. something desperate.
That of course will require serious consideration.
GWENDOLEN. I will communicate with you daily.
JACK. My own one!
GWENDOLEN. How long do you remain in town?
JACK. Till Monday.
GWENDOLEN. Good!

ALGERNON. Thanks, I’ve turned round already.
GWENDOLEN. You may also ring the bell.
JACK. You will let me see you to your carriage, my own darling?
GWENDOLEN. Certainly.
JACK. To Lane, who now enters.
I will see Miss Fairfax out.
LANE. Yes, sir.
Jack and Gwendolen go off.
LANE. Lane presents several letters on a salver to Algernon.
It is to be
LANE. surmised that they are bills, as Algernon, after looking at the

ALGERNON. A glass of sherry, Lane.

ALGERNON. To-morrow, Lane, I’m going Bunburying.
LANE. Yes, sir.
ALGERNON. I shall probably not be back till Monday.

ALGERNON. clothes, my smoking jacket, and all the Bunbury suits...

JACK. There’s a sensible, intellectual girl! the only girl I ever cared for
JACK. in my life.

JACK. so amused at?
ALGERNON. Oh, I’m a little anxious about poor Bunbury, that is all.

JACK. Oh, that’s nonsense, Algy.

ALGERNON. Nobody ever does.
ALGERNON. Jack looks indignantly at him, and leaves the room.

ALGERNON. cigarette, reads his shirt-cuff, and smiles.
ALGERNON. SECOND ACT

chapters.title: ACT II. The Garden at the Manor House, Woolton.

sentences: Garden at the Manor House.
A flight of grey stone steps leads up to the
house.
The garden, an old-fashioned one, full of roses.
Time of year,
July.
Basket chairs, and a table covered with books, are set under a
large yew-tree.
Miss Prism discovered seated at the table.
Cecily is at the back
watering flowers.
MISS PRISM.
Calling.
Cecily, Cecily!
Surely such a utilitarian occupation as the
watering of flowers is rather Moulton’s duty than yours?
Especially at
a moment when intellectual pleasures await you.
Your German grammar is
on the table.
Pray open it at page fifteen.
We will repeat yesterday’s
lesson.
CECILY. Coming over very slowly.
But I don’t like German.
It isn’t at all a
CECILY. becoming language.
I know perfectly well that I look quite plain after
CECILY. my German lesson.
CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Child, you know how anxious your guardian is that you should improve
CECILY. yourself in every way.
He laid particular stress on your German, as he
CECILY. was leaving for town yesterday.
Indeed, he always lays stress on your
CECILY. German when he is leaving for town.
CECILY. Dear Uncle Jack is so very serious!
Sometimes he is so serious that I
CECILY. think he cannot be quite well.
CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Drawing herself up.
Your guardian enjoys the best of health, and his
CECILY. gravity of demeanour is especially to be commended in one so
CECILY. comparatively young as he is.
I know no one who has a higher sense of
CECILY. duty and responsibility.
CECILY. I suppose that is why he often looks a little bored when we three are
CECILY. together.
CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Cecily!
I am surprised at you.
Mr. Worthing has many troubles in his
CECILY. Idle merriment and triviality would be out of place in his
CECILY. conversation.
You must remember his constant anxiety about that
CECILY. unfortunate young man his brother.
CECILY. I wish Uncle Jack would allow that unfortunate young man, his brother,
CECILY. to come down here sometimes.
We might have a good influence over him,
CECILY. Miss Prism.
I am sure you certainly would.
You know German, and
CECILY. geology, and things of that kind influence a man very much.
Cecily
CECILY. begins to write in her diary.
CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Shaking her head.
I do not think that even I could produce any effect
CECILY. on a character that according to his own brother’s admission is
CECILY. irretrievably weak and vacillating.
Indeed I am not sure that I would
CECILY. desire to reclaim him.
I am not in favour of this modern mania for
CECILY. turning bad people into good people at a moment’s notice.
As a man sows
CECILY. so let him reap.
You must put away your diary, Cecily.
I really don’t
CECILY. see why you should keep a diary at all.
CECILY. I keep a diary in order to enter the wonderful secrets of my life.
CECILY. didn’t write them down, I should probably forget all about them.
CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Memory, my dear Cecily, is the diary that we all carry about with us.
CECILY. Yes, but it usually chronicles the things that have never happened, and
CECILY. couldn’t possibly have happened.

CECILY. for nearly all the three-volume novels that Mudie sends us.
CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Do not speak slightingly of the three-volume novel, Cecily.
I wrote one
CECILY. myself in earlier days.
CECILY. Did you really, Miss Prism?

CECILY. did not end happily?

CECILY. me so much.

CECILY. The good ended happily, and the bad unhappily.

CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Alas! no.
The manuscript unfortunately was abandoned.
Cecily starts.
CECILY. I use the word in the sense of lost or mislaid.
To your work, child,
CECILY. these speculations are profitless.
CECILY. Smiling.

CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Rising and advancing.
Dr. Chasuble!

CHASUBLE. And how are we this morning?

CECILY. Miss Prism has just been complaining of a slight headache.
I think it
CECILY. would do her so much good to have a short stroll with you in the Park,
CECILY. Dr. Chasuble.
CECILY. MISS PRISM.
CECILY. Cecily, I have not mentioned anything about a headache.
CECILY. No, dear Miss Prism, I know that, but I felt instinctively that you had
CECILY. a headache.

CECILY. Oh, I am afraid I am.
CHASUBLE. That is strange.

CHASUBLE. would hang upon her lips.

I spoke

Gwendolen and Cecily are at the window, looking out into the garden.
GWENDOLEN. The fact that they did not follow us at once into the house, as any one
GWENDOLEN. else would have done, seems to me to show that they have some sense of
GWENDOLEN. shame left.
CECILY. They have been eating muffins.

GWENDOLEN. After a pause.
They don’t seem to notice us at all.
Couldn’t you
GWENDOLEN. cough?
CECILY. But I haven’t got a cough.
GWENDOLEN. They’re looking at us.

CECILY. They’re approaching.

GWENDOLEN. Let us preserve a dignified silence.
CECILY. Certainly.

Enter Jack followed by
CECILY. Algernon.
They whistle some dreadful popular air from a British Opera.
GWENDOLEN. This dignified silence seems to produce an unpleasant effect.
CECILY. A most distasteful one.
GWENDOLEN. But we will not be the first to speak.
CECILY. Certainly not.
GWENDOLEN. Mr. Worthing, I have something very particular to ask you.
Much depends
GWENDOLEN. on your reply.
CECILY. Gwendolen, your common sense is invaluable.
Mr. Moncrieff, kindly
CECILY. answer me the following question.
